--- title: "Grammar of data transformation" subtitle: "Lecture 3" date: "2025-01-21" format: revealjs auto-stretch: false --- # Now, where was I? ## Alison Bechdel ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/03/alison.png){fig-align="center" width="80%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/03/fun_home.jpg){fig-align="center" width="80%"} ::: ::: ## The Bechdel Test ::: columns ::: {.column width="72%"} ![](images/03/bechdel.png){fig-align="center"} (*Dykes to Watch Out For* - 1985) ::: ::: {.column width="28%"} Film passes if... 1. two female characters; 2. talk to each other; 3. about something besides a man. ::: ::: ## Do JZ's favorite movies pass? | | | |-----------------------------------------|-----| | *Double Indemnity* (1944) | ðŸ¥´ | | *Sunset Boulevard* (1950) | ðŸ¥´ | | *Sweet Smell of Success* (1957) | âŒ | | *One Hundred and One Dalmatians* (1961) | âœ… | | *Chinatown* (1974) | âŒ | | *Amadeus* (1984) | âŒ | | *Goodfellas* (1990) | ðŸ¥´ | | *Bram Stoker's Dracula* (1992) | âŒ | | *The Lord of the Rings* (2001 - 2003) | âŒ | | *Vera Drake* (2004) | âœ… | ## Our starting point ::: callout-note ## From [FiveThirtyEight](https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-dollar-and-cents-case-against-hollywoods-exclusion-of-women/) ![](images/03/five_thirty_eight.png){fig-align="center" width="85%"} ::: "We did a statistical analysis of films to test two claims: first, that films that pass the Bechdel test â€” featuring women in stronger roles â€” see a lower return on investment, and second, that they see lower gross profits. We found no evidence to support either claim." ## `ae-02-bechdel-dataviz` ::: appex Go to RStudio, confirm that you're in the `ae` project, and open the document ae-02-bechdel-dataviz`.qmd`. ::: ## Recap: Code cells (aka code chunks) {.smaller} ![](images/03/code-cell.png) . . . - Cell `label`s are helpful for describing what the code is doing, for jumping between code cells in the editor, and for troubleshooting - `message: false` hides any messages emitted by the code in your rendered document # Describing distributions and relationships ## Talking about one numerical variable ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-grammar-of-data-transformation_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-grammar-of-data-transformation_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: - **center**: what is the "typical" value (mean, median, mode) the data are concentrating around? - **spread**: how concentrated are the data around a typical value? - **shape**: does the distribution have one peak, or many? is it symmetric or skewed? ## Interaction between shape and center ![](images/03/mean_median_mode.png) ## Histograms provide more detail... ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-grammar-of-data-transformation_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-grammar-of-data-transformation_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## ...but boxplots are nice for side-by-side comparisons ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-grammar-of-data-transformation_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960} ::: ::: ## Talking about two numerical variables ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](03-grammar-of-data-transformation_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){fig-align='center' width=864} ::: ::: - **direction**: positive or negative - **shape**: linear or nonlinear - **strength**: how close are points to the "trend" ## Strength and direction of linear relationships ![](images/03/corr-example.png) ## Nonlinear relationships ![](images/02/un-data-viz.png) # Data transformation ## A quick reminder {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bechdel |> # <1> filter(roi > 400) |> # <2> select(title, roi, budget_2013, gross_2013, year, clean_test) # <3> ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 Ã— 6 title roi budget_2013 gross_2013 year clean_test 1 Paranormal Activity 671. 505595 339424558 2007 dubious 2 The Blair Witch Project 648. 839077 543776715 1999 ok 3 El Mariachi 583. 11622 6778946 1992 nowomen ``` ::: ::: 1. Start with the `bechdel` data frame 2. Filter for movies with `roi` greater than 400 (gross is more than 400 times budget) 3. Select the columns `title`, `roi`, `budget_2013`, `gross_2013`, `year`, and `clean_test` ## The pipe `|>` {.smaller} The pipe operator passes what comes before it into the function that comes after it as the first argument in that function. ::: columns ::: {.column .fragment width="55%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sum(1, 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column .fragment width="45%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} 1 |> sum(2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::
::: columns ::: {.column .fragment width="55%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} select(filter(bechdel, roi > 400), title) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 Ã— 1 title 1 Paranormal Activity 2 The Blair Witch Project 3 El Mariachi ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column .fragment width="45%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bechdel |> filter(roi > 400) |> select(title) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 Ã— 1 title 1 Paranormal Activity 2 The Blair Witch Project 3 El Mariachi ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Code style tip {{< fa lightbulb >}} {.smaller} - In data transformation pipelines, always use a - space before `|>` - line break after `|>` - indent the next line of code . . . - In data visualization layers, always use a - space before `+` - line break after `+` - indent the next line of code ## The pipe, in action {.smaller} ::: task Find movies that pass the Bechdel test and display their titles and ROIs in descending order of ROI. ::: . . . Start with the `bechdel` data frame: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bechdel ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1,615 Ã— 7 title year gross_2013 budget_2013 roi binary clean_test 1 21 & Over 2013 67878146 13000000 5.22 FAIL notalk 2 Dredd 3D 2012 55078343 45658735 1.21 PASS ok 3 12 Years a Slave 2013 211714070 20000000 10.6 FAIL notalk 4 2 Guns 2013 208105475 61000000 3.41 FAIL notalk 5 42 2013 190040426 40000000 4.75 FAIL men 6 47 Ronin 2013 184166317 225000000 0.819 FAIL men 7 A Good Day to Die Hard 2013 371598396 92000000 4.04 FAIL notalk 8 About Time 2013 102648667 12000000 8.55 PASS ok 9 Admission 2013 36014634 13000000 2.77 PASS ok 10 After Earth 2013 304895295 130000000 2.35 FAIL notalk # â„¹ 1,605 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## The pipe, in action {.smaller} ::: task Find movies that pass the Bechdel test and display their titles and ROIs in descending order of ROI. ::: Filter for rows where `binary` is equal to `"PASS"`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bechdel |> filter(binary == "PASS") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 753 Ã— 7 title year gross_2013 budget_2013 roi binary clean_test 1 Dredd 3D 2012 55078343 45658735 1.21 PASS ok 2 About Time 2013 102648667 12000000 8.55 PASS ok 3 Admission 2013 36014634 13000000 2.77 PASS ok 4 American Hustle 2013 397915817 40000000 9.95 PASS ok 5 August: Osage County 2013 87609748 25000000 3.50 PASS ok 6 Beautiful Creatures 2013 75392809 50000000 1.51 PASS ok 7 Blue Jasmine 2013 101793664 18000000 5.66 PASS ok 8 Carrie 2013 120268278 30000000 4.01 PASS ok 9 Despicable Me 2 2013 1338831390 76000000 17.6 PASS ok 10 Elysium 2013 379242208 120000000 3.16 PASS ok # â„¹ 743 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## The pipe, in action {.smaller} ::: task Find movies that pass the Bechdel test and display their titles and ROIs in descending order of ROI. ::: Arrange the rows in `desc`ending order of `roi`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bechdel |> filter(binary == "PASS") |> arrange(desc(roi)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 753 Ã— 7 title year gross_2013 budget_2013 roi binary clean_test 1 The Blair Witch Project 1999 543776715 839077 648. PASS ok 7 Paranormal Activity 2 2010 280159759 3204696 87.4 PASS ok 8 Paranormal Activity 3 2011 322170936 5178454 62.2 PASS ok 9 The Last Exorcism 2010 118787648 1922817 61.8 PASS ok 10 Cinderella 1997 246710482 4208591 58.6 PASS ok # â„¹ 743 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## The pipe, in action {.smaller} ::: task Find movies that pass the Bechdel test and display their titles and ROIs in descending order of ROI. ::: Select columns `title` and `roi`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bechdel |> filter(binary == "PASS") |> arrange(desc(roi)) |> select(title, roi) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 753 Ã— 2 title roi 1 The Blair Witch Project 648. 2 The Devil Inside 155. 3 My Big Fat Greek Wedding 119. 4 Chasing Amy 109. 5 Slacker 107. 6 Insidious 103. 7 Paranormal Activity 2 87.4 8 Paranormal Activity 3 62.2 9 The Last Exorcism 61.8 10 Cinderella 58.6 # â„¹ 743 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## In this class, you will... ::: columns ::: {.column width="35%"} Build cakes (`ggplot`) ![](images/03/cake.jpg) ::: ::: {.column width="65%"} Stack dolls (pipe `|>`) ![](images/03/matryoshka.jpg) ::: ::: Master these constructs, and everything will be coming up roses!

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
